title: 114_hr2625
content: The "Bailout Prevention Act of 2015" may be cited as such. It includes discounts for individuals, partnerships, and corporations. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to establish procedures prohibiting borrowing from programs by insolvent borrowers. Borrowers must be certified as not insolvent by the Board and Federal banking regulators before borrowing from emergency lending programs. Solvency is determined by comparing the fair value of assets to liabilities based on the last 4 months of financial data. The borrower's solvency is determined by comparing the fair value of liabilities with adjustments for temporary illiquidity. Insolvency is defined as being in bankruptcy, resolution proceedings, or being a bridge financial company. The institution must issue a public statement explaining a certification of solvency made by the Board or banking regulator. A program or facility must have broad-based eligibility with at least 5 eligible companies participating significantly. SEC. 3. PENALTY RATE REQUIREMENT; CONGRESSIONAL APPROVAL REQUIREMENT. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require emergency lending at an interest rate 500 basis points higher than the Treasury's borrowing cost. The Board can create lending programs not meeting certain requirements but must report to Congress within 3 days. The Board must report to Congress within 3 days if a program or facility does not meet requirements. If Congress does not approve within 30 days, the program or facility will terminate. The program or facility loans must be repaid within 30 days of termination. A joint resolution must be introduced within 3 days of receiving the report to approve the program or facility. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System creates a program or facility that Congress must approve within 3 days of receiving a report. The House must convene within two days after receiving the report. The House committee must report a joint resolution within 5 days of receiving a report, or it will be discharged. After committee review, the joint resolution must be considered within 6 days of Congress receiving the report. The House committee must report a joint resolution within 5 days of receiving a report, or it will be discharged. The motion to proceed to consider the joint resolution in the House is non-debatable and must be considered as ordered without any intervening motion. The joint resolution shall be considered as read, and all points of order against it are waived. The joint resolution shall be considered as ordered for passage without debate, except for 2 hours of debate. A motion to reconsider the vote on passage is not allowed. The majority leader of the Senate must notify members to convene within 2 days of receiving a report if the Senate has adjourned. Upon introduction in the Senate, the joint resolution is immediately placed on the calendar. It is in order to move to proceed to the consideration of the joint resolution within a specific timeframe, with all points of order waived. The motion to proceed is not debatable. The motion to proceed to the consideration of the joint resolution is not debatable and not subject to a motion to postpone. If agreed to, the joint resolution will remain unfinished business until disposed of. Debate on the resolution is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between majority and minority leaders. Additional motions to limit debate are in order and not debatable. The vote on passage of a joint resolution shall occur immediately following the conclusion of the debate, with appeals from the Chair's decisions decided without debate. If one House receives a joint resolution from the other House before passing its own, it will be considered. If one House fails to introduce or consider a joint resolution, the resolution from the other House will receive expedited floor procedures. If the Senate receives a companion measure from the House of Representatives after passing a joint resolution, the companion measure will not be debatable. If the President vetoes the joint resolution, the time between the veto and Congress receiving the veto message will not count towards the 30-day period for debate on the veto message in the Senate. The subclauses enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the Senate and House of Representatives, applicable only with respect to the procedure for a joint resolution, superseding other rules to the extent of inconsistency, recognizing the constitutional right of either House to change the rules. The rules can be changed in the same manner and to the same extent as any other rule of the House. SEC. 4. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION RELATED TO CREDIT FACILITIES. Amendments are made to shorten the timeframes for reports on GAO audits and public disclosures by the Board of Governors under the Federal Reserve Act. The changes include reducing the reporting period from 1 year to 60 days for GAO audits and from 24 months to 60 days for public disclosures. Amendments shorten reporting timeframes for GAO audits and public disclosures under the Federal Reserve Act. Reporting period reduced from 1 year to 60 days for GAO audits and from 24 months to 60 days for public disclosures. Subsection (s) redesignated as subsection (t).
